results.title: Simple plants: the algae
results.brief_description: Illustrates typical forms of algae, explains their structure and traces their evolutionary development. Also shows reporductuve processes. From the series “Biology Program. Unit 2. Plant Life.”

results.title: Simple plants: Algae and fungi
results.brief_description: Descibes major characteristics of simple plants and shows how they differ from higher plants; shows their natural habitat; explains major differences between algae and fungi; and points out diverse human uses of algae and fungi.

results.title: Simple multicellular animals: sponges, coelenterates and flatworms
results.brief_description: Begins with a study of volvox and then moves to sponges, coelenterates and flatworms as examples of multicellular animals. Covers anatomy, nerve structure, fading strategies and reproduction. No other credits available.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with water
results.brief_description: Demonstrations to illustrate that water has surface tension which acts like a film over it, that water exerts pressure, and that water can produce a buoyant force.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with static electricity
results.brief_description: Demonstrates basic concepts of static electricity. Shows that friction can produce static electricity, that both positive and negative charges can be created, that identical charges repel and opposite charges attract, and that all matter is electrically charged.
results.description: Demonstrates basic concepts of static electricity. Shows that friction can produce static electricity, that both positive and negative charges can be created, that identical charges repel and opposite charges attract, and that all matter is electrically charged.

results.title: Simple demonstrations with magnetism
results.brief_description: Interesting demonstrations and experiments explain and illustrate the basic concepts of magnetism: magnets can produce a force, magnets have poles, magnets can make other magnets, and the earth is a magnet. Many of the experiments can be repeated in the classroom, while others use equipment not available in most schools.
results.description: Interesting demonstrations and experiments explain and illustrate the basic concepts of magnetism: magnets can produce a force, magnets have poles, magnets can make other magnets, and the earth is a magnet. Many of the experiments can be repeated in the classroom, while others use equipment not available in most schools.
